lines.text: Two bits, four bits, six bits, a peso. All for Zorro, stand up and say so!
They say the Navy makes men. I'm living proof - they made ME!
[last lines]
If I give my land to the people, where are we going to live?
Boston!
Boston?
Yes! It is the only civilized city. They have the best art, the best music...
You have to be kidding me! I was in Boston for a week, and I never heard a decent Mariachi playing.

[to guards]
Remember, he is cunning, he is crafty. He's not just going to walk in here and say 'Here I am!'
Here I am!

[teasing Charlotte Taylor Wilson]
Do you think you are helping the pipple by telling them they have an occent when they do not have an occent?
[after spraining his ankle]
My father would be very disappointed in me. To have come all this way and miss my destiny by... a foot.
Is your blade as sharp as your tongue?
Is yours as dull as your wit?
Why didn't I marry you instead of Esteban?
Probably because he asked you and I did not.
I'm Charlotte Taylor Wilson. I'm with the People's Independence Committee.
Don Diego Vega. I'm with the greedy bloodsuckers.
You don't really believe the people are happy!
All I know is the soldiers are quite happy shooting the people who say the people are not happy.
He is a mute.
Bueno! Perhaps he can give lessons to my wife.
What commands priests to wear such strange clothing?
We are followers of Peter the Dressmaker. He was Christ's tailor.

[to Diego]
Know me? Sink me! We were once womb-mates!
Say something like a sissy girl.
Something like a sissy girl...
No... you know. Swing... your... hips.
[puts hands on hips]
Make them sway and flap your wings.
There is e-somethin' wrong wid joo bowels
[vowels]
My what?
Joo bowels. Joo a's, joo e's joo i's, o's, u's.
A little clumsy, are you not, my friend?
To be your friend I would have to be more than clumsy. I would have to be stupid.
What do the people need roads for? They never go anywhere.
Los Angeles, California. The birthplace of... me.
It is a beautiful day... for a Reign of *terror*!

[hiding in a box, where Esteban's angry sword thrust has just narrowly missed skewering her breasts]
Thank goodness for small favors!

[regarding Esteban]
Do you know he only makes love to me 12 times a year?
Well, once a month is not so bad.
No, he makes love to me 12 times in one night and then, zip, nothing!
Tell me, on that one night, does he eat anything special? Oysters? Raw eggs?
Garlic. A lot of garlic.
I have always depended on people being nicer than me, and I have never in my life been disappointed.
There is no shame in being poor! Only in dressing poorly!
You recognize that famous sign, eh?
Oh, yes, Señor. It is the number 2.
That is a not a 2! It is a Z!
Oh, if you say so, Señor. But in the school, that is how they teach my granddaughter to draw a Two.
*I* say it is a *Z* - For El Zorro!

[kisses his boot]
Zorro! Oh, thank God you're back!
Spread the news, that he is back! To help the helpless! To befriend the friendless! And to defeat... er, the "featless."
You naughty, evil Alcalde! I'm going to do such terrible things to you!
[Diego is about to be shot]
You're the bravest man I've ever met.
I'm very impressed with myself, too.
Black is tacky.

[with un-painted side of face showing, speaking like a woman]
Help! Help! The Alcalde has all my money!

[turns around, with this side of face painted like Zorro, speaking very slowly and deeply]
Have no fear, El Zorro is here!
Where is your invitation, Senor Beaver?

[threatening Charlotte Taylor Wilson with execution in order to lure and trap Zorro]
Do you wish for a blindfold?
No. The eyes of freedom will always see through the blindfolds of tyranny. And the bonds of oppression will always be broken with muscles of liberty.

[to Zorro]
I know you will not kill an innocent man... or me either, for that matter.

[Zorro about to be executed in her place]
I have only one regret... that you will not live to see the glorious revolution that you have brought about...

[to himself]
Why doesn't she say something like, I will love you forever? When's she going to say that?
I will love you forever!
How can there be two of you?
You always say, when the revolution came, there would be more for everyone.
What I would give to have one night in your bootsies.
In my Bootsies?
He wears his clothes well. I could never get into his pants.
I bet I could.
Bravo, my brother. You've really proven yourself tonight. Is there anything I can do to make you change your mind about staying?

I'm afraid not. In two days from now, my ship sails for England. But tell Esteban that if he wants to keep in touch with me, tell him to write to 'Wiggy' of the Royal Navy based in Portsmouth. But only if he's serious.

[Referring to their annual lovemaking]
Do you know that little thing we do one night every year?

[Eagerly]
Yes! Oh, yes!
We still have three months to go!
You beast!

[First lines]
In the late part of the 18th century, the peasants of California were oppressed by tyrannical land owners. To protect the poor and downtrodden people, there emerged a mysterious swordsman who pledged his life in the service of justice. To the people, he was a great hero who would live forever in their hearts. To the landowners, however, he was a real pain in the ass. He was known only as... Zorro!
[Zorro has backed the evil soldier Garcia against a tree, and carved a 'Z' in the tree trunk above his head]
Does that not strike terror in your heart?
No, Señor. B-but I'm new to the region!
You do not recognize and fear the sign, the mark... of El Zorro?

[lifts up his eyepatch to look at it]
I love it!
[Garcia describes his encounter with Zorro to Esteban]
He said his name was, er..."Zero!"
[the landowners meet to elect a new Alcade. Each introduces himself to the others,]
Don Diego from San Fernando.
Don Francisco from San Jose.
Don Fernando from San Diego.
Don Jose from San Bernardino.
Luis Obispo from Bakersfield.
I say, I'd like my little soldier doll, again.
You'd like what?
Oh, come come, you remember the doll perfectly well. Blue button eyes, tall hat? We called him, Colonel Puh-Pah.
Colonel Puh-Pah? I know you?
Know me? Sink me! We we're once womb-mates.
Womb-mates? Ramon? Ramon! Ramon, my brother's back! Ramon, I can't believe it. Ramon!
Yes, I'd rather liked that, womb-mates. Yes yes, ha ha ha ha ha.
After twenty years, I can't believe it! Ramon!

Well, I was Ramon, twenty years ago, when father decided it wasn't quite masculine enough, so he shipped me off to sea in a British frigate. They say the navy makes men. Well, I'm living proof they made me.
Here, Paco, take the horse from my brother, pronto. You says you were Ramon? You no longer Ramon Viega, Ramon?
No no, I've dishanded that Latin tradition. I'm Bunny Wigglesworth, now.
I can't believe it, my brother's just so different.
Yeah, well your still the same, aren't you? Still tan, bland, and, uh?
Romantic, huh?
No no, I was about to say, randy. How did you hurt your foot then? Falling off a tavern maid?
No, I broke it fighting against tyrannies and injustices, and for the trodden down peoples, and the little babies, and the...
Well, I'm sure it's all quite an amusing little story, but I ought to freshen up and say 'Hi-ho' to the Old Gent! Tell me, is he still as loud as ever?
No, the last month he's been very... quiet...
